=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown of what’s going on in this game:

• Game Genre:
 – It’s a space shooter arcade game. Think of it as a retro-style fixed shooter (a bit like Space Invaders) where you pilot a spaceship and face off against waves of enemy aliens and their projectiles.

• Main Game Elements and Mechanics:
 – You control an avatar—a spaceship that can maneuver across the screen. It can fire a blue projectile (“sam”) to attack enemies.
 – There’s also a stationary “base” (a planet), which seems to be an object you need to protect. It interacts with both your projectiles and enemy bombs.
 – The enemies come in the form of “alien” sprites that are programmed to act like bombers. They drop red bombs that slowly travel downward.
 – In addition, there are “missiles,” which are also projectiles with their own behavior when they hit the edge of the screen.
 – The game uses “portals” (invisible spawn points marked as “portalSlow” and “portalFast”) to periodically generate new enemy aliens. These portals have cooldown timers and a fixed total number of spawns.
 – The level layout places stationary formations (marked with zeros) and initially positions the player (the “A” on the map) among obstacles or safe regions.

• How the Interactions Work:
 – When your spaceship (the avatar) reaches the edge of the screen (EOS), it “steps back” to stay within bounds.
 – Enemies bounce off the screen edges.
 – Your blue shots (“sam”) can collide with various objects. For example, if they hit the base, both the base and the bullet vanish (and you gain a small score), so you have to be careful not to damage your own base.
 – There are several collision outcomes with associated score changes. For instance:
  • If a missile touches the edge of the screen, it’s simply removed.
  • If an enemy bomb hits the base, both are destroyed.
  • If an enemy alien collides with your spaceship, it is removed but you lose points—so contact with enemies or their bombs is risky.
  • On the other hand, if your blue shot connects with an alien, it removes the enemy and can award you bonus points.

• Objective and When You Win or Lose:
 – Losing: You lose if your avatar is destroyed (i.e., when no spaceship remains).
 – Winning: Victory comes when you completely eliminate all enemy aliens and also clear out the enemy spawn points (portals). In other words, you must shut down the source of the enemy waves and remove all aliens from the playing field.

• Overall Strategy:
 1. Stay agile and keep your spaceship away from incoming enemy bombs and aliens. Maneuvering is key since letting an enemy or bomb hit you costs points and risks your survival.
 2. Aim carefully with your blue shots (“sam”) to take down enemy aliens from a distance. Targeting them before they drop bombs or get too close is essential.
 3. Protect your base by avoiding friendly fire—be mindful that your own projectiles can accidentally damage it—and by intercepting enemy bombs if possible.
 4. Focus on eliminating the portals first or concurrently with the aliens. Since these spawn new enemies (with different cooldowns and speeds), clearing them stops the continuous pressure.
 5. Balance offense and defense: aggressive shooting to rack up the positive score while dodging enemy fire and collisions is crucial to not only scoring well but also to staying alive.

By combining careful maneuvering, precise targeting, and proactive management of enemy spawns, you can work toward eliminating threats, safeguarding your assets, and ultimately clearing the level to win the game.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
